title.narrative: RMI - coal phase-out in Indonesia and Vietnam

description.narrative:
To facilitate coal phase-out in Indonesia and Vietnam by: 1. Develop a common fact base to align decision makers and supporting organizations on optimal power transition pathways. 2. Design financial mechanisms for piloting in Vietnam and Indonesia. 3. Define a path for early coal phaseout in Vietnam and Indonesia.
RMI’s approach to achieving an effective, rapid coal phaseout rests on the development of innovative and inclusive financial approaches that support key decision-makers to pursue pathways to declining coal utilization, ramp-up clean energy investment, and facilitate a just transition for workers and communities. To achieve these outcomes, our work is centered on three priorities: Refinancing coal capital costs on the condition of power plant owners committing to an accelerated phase out, which frees up capital to help fund coal transition while lowering customer costs; Reinvesting in clean energy, which allows owners to phase out coal plants and reduce customer costs further while replacing returns from coal plants with returns from clean energy; and Transition financing for coal workers and communities, raised in part through refinancing, which offers immediate resources to preserve livelihoods, protect benefits, and ensure that host communities can continue to thrive.

sector.narrative: Energy sector policy, planning and administration

title.narrative: Indonesia: The RUKN and the NDC indicate a clear pathway to no new coal additions, and expedited retirement leading to a total decline in coal capacity.

comment.narrative: Indonesia: The General Plan of National Electricity (RUKN) initially targeted 19% renewable penetration by 2025, and regulatory updates from the Ministry of Energy and Natural Resources increased the target to 23%. These updates include signals that up to 13 GW of fossil fuels will be retired, though that includes some diesel to be converted to gas or coal gasification. Given COVID economic concerns, many of the power development plans remain at risk, and the Low Carbon Development Plan led by BAPPENAS appears less influential.

title.narrative: Vietnam: PDP 9 and the NDC indicate a clear pathway to no new coal capacity additions, a revised target for 2035 that includes a decline in total coal capacity, and a higher share of renewables in 2030 and 2035 compared to PDP 8.

comment.narrative: Vietnam: Initial results from the draft Power Development Plan (PDP) 8 indicates a slowdown in the scale of coal development and an emphasis on expanding renewables and gas power generation. Energy security remains a significant concern, in particular given Vietnam has significantly increased coal imports over the last three years and continues to rely on electricity imports from China.
